FacilityName: Laurel Pipe Line Company, L.P.- Booth Station

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fill shut-off device at 90%, alarm at 80%, Class 1, Div.1 electrical from transfer point to 5ft.  Class I, Div.2 from 5-15ft., Labels on cylinders (NFPA 704, Not Odorized, No Smoking, etc.)
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Portable 20 lb. fire extinguishers and hydrants.  Excess flow valves, pressure relief valves.  Thermal actuated valves.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Temperature, Pressure, and Level Indicators w/alarms/shut-offs.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Vessels, pipes, emergency shut-down systems, signage, grounding/bonding, security and fire systems.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Laurel Pipe Line Company, L.P.- Booth Station was constructed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association Code #58 (2004 Edition) for Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is the Facility's policy to follow the most current edition (2011) to the extent feasible and adhere to all Federal, State, and Local codes/laws.  Notable modifications to the process included the addition of a third offload station.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the Facility's policy to contact the Bethel Township Fire Department and the Delaware County LEPC, as appropriate throught the 911 Service.  Medical emergencies will require notification of Concord 59 and Talleyville 25 (both Basic Life Support Units) or Medic 104 (Advanced Life Support unit) via 911 for ambulance service.  The primary hospital response is provided through Crozier Chester Medical Center with support through Riddle Hospital.  The Facility currently maintains a trained incipient stage fire response and first responder-operations level hazardous materials response teams to respond to the initial stages of an emergency.

The Laurel Pipe Line Company, L.P.- Booth Station is a refined product pipeline breakout station, including the butane blending system (direct injection into the pipelines).  The Risk Management Plan covers the butane blending system including three 60,000 gallon vessels and the associated piping, blending skid, two sampling units, and two truck off-loading points.

The Facility's worst case scenerio is the failure of a single butane vessel resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The Facility's alternate release scenario was also calculated based on impact and likelihood.

The Laurel Pipe Line Company, L.P.- Booth Station complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D- Program Level 3).  Additionally, this plan meets the requirements of the U.S. Department of Labor- Occupational Safety and Health Administration's

Process Safety Management regulations (inclusive of all 14 elements) for Highly Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR Part 1910.119).  This butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained to meet of exceed the NFPA #58 requirements for Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage.

To date, this Facility has never had an accident or incident involving the butane blending system resulting in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering-in-place.

In the event of an emergency involving the Booth Station butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Bethel Township Fire Department and request their assistance.  The Facility maintains a trained (annual) incipient fire and hazardous material response team, as referenced above.  The Facility's Emergency Response Plans are coordinated with the Bethel Township Fire Department and the Delaware County LEPC.  The Bethel County Fire Department is aware of the Facility's butane blending system.  Fire Deparment access is via Garnet Mine Road.  Available fire protection includes a Facility deluge system (5 foam monitors), nine hydrants, and portable (20 lb.) dry chemical fire extinguishers.  The Booth Station maintains a vegetation control plan to minimize plant growth within 10 feet of the butane vessels.

Buckeye continually evaluates the process for opportunities to improve safety.  Currently, the addition of a ground interlock system and additional thermal reliefs is being evaluated.  Also, Buckeye is considering a corporate-wide policy to include the local first responders in all 3 year PSM/RMP training cycles.
